page.title: 11WILDLIFE IN THE PARISH (1)
page.content: The Colne Valley gravel pits represent a significant bird habitat,providing a natural migration route - especially in Spring.The pits are used by wintering wildfowl,whose numbers reach a peak around the end of January.Some representative counts in the last five years include the following: 350 Tufted Duck; 150 Pochard; 200 Mallard; 30-35 Goldeneye,Wigeon,Teal, Shoveler and Gadwall.A large flock of up to 300 Canada Geese and 50 Greylag Geese frequent the area in winter, together with some rarer varieties. In early April the Spring movements begin,culminating in the establishment of local breeding populations by the beginning of June.Most commonly seen at this time of the year are Sedge, Reed and Willow Warblers,Chiffchaffs, Blackcaps and Spotted Flycatchers. The surrounding woods attract Kestrels,
